are the things I wanted to share about so you guys know Conway's law any
organization that designs the system will inevitably produce a design whose structure is a copy of the
organization's communication structure there are various versions of this but I'm you end up reading this a lot when
you read about DevOps or you read about microservices and you know this is
something we found you know being an old organization that's been doing a lot of these things for many years we have seen
that you know there's sort of a corollary to Conway's law which is that
our communication structures have evolved to match the legacy systems that
we have to maintain so in some sense we look like these these monolithic
vertical applications that we may have made in the 90s or the early 2000s and in other senses our communication
structures look like a sort of an mV see layered architecture and so the real
insight for us though was that the technology and the people mirror one another and are inseparable so if you
want to change the technology you have to liberate the people and that's we're
going to talk a little bit about this is a photograph of us releasing SAT scores at 5:00 a.m. last year that's a that's a
visual manifestation of Conway's law we had to have everybody in the room like a
NASA launch right propulsion check telemetry check
meteorology check right that's that's kind of what we have to do and these are really I have to say I enjoy these
they're fun I see the leader of of these here in the audience today but the thing
about it is that this is a physical manifestation of Conway's law because there are inter dependencies between
teams and when there are inter dependencies between teams inevitably you end up impeding individual teams
from innovating what we're trying to get to is when you work on one of our teams it feels like you're in a start-up
because there's nothing impeding you yes you have controls you have automation you have CI CD you have security check
you have all of that but you're able to release on your own in a DevOps manner
and not having to consult with seven teams that you may harm by innovating
this is a diagram we created to kind of represent the Conway's law in which we
live the circles one through ten represent teams the teams are receiving user
stories let's call them an epics from the business owners who want things from
them who need who need to deliver value and on the bottom we have all this inter
communication that needs to happen between teams to operate a monolith and so again drawing from Conway's law what
we wanted to begin to do first of all using agile was to take that that sense
of team's having to answer to so many distinct product owners and fix that by adopting agile so that teams are
a single product backlog in a single product owner and that helped a ton but we still had all those interconnections
in between individual assets and you know I'm looking out here today you guys
chose to came to come to this session many of you work in a.gov or.org
environment and the the nice thing about
being in one of those environments and and I think something that we really learned is that we may not compete you

day and I think a key lesson for us has been that technologists do not like
working in back waters they don't want to work in a backwater but if and therefore if we create an

of yolk this together by a set of principles that should be familiar to you we call them the North Stars
now there's only one North Star right but we took a little creative license
